meta_data.title: Bonus Episode on Casting Lots
meta_data.subtitle: Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "Bonus Episode (Bonus Episode)" by

transcription_data.text: 🎵 Bonus episode, a bonus episode Of the 10 minute Bible hour podcast It's a bonus episode, a bonus episode Of the 10 minute Bible hour podcast Come on now! 🎵 Hey everybody, it's Matt, this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast And if you happen to be listening to this in real time, then you're like, wait a minute, this is Saturday We don't do this on Saturdays, but you're wrong! Sometimes we do it on Saturdays, this is one of those days I thought we just had a really fun week of talking about the biblical concept of casting lots and dice and Cleromancy and using some form of what looks on the surface like chance to determine the will of God It's an odd practice, I'm not saying do that or don't do that But what I am saying is that all those examples that we came up with Mostly at the top of my head, really easily and really quickly throughout the Bible There's none of them cast a negative light on the practice or discourage it At worst, the treatment by the biblical authors is indifference or neutrality And at best, the indication is, no, I mean casting lots in that situation Was a way to figure out the will of God or at least to get unstuck and move forward And I'm very sorry for my voice, this has been a long journey for me, so I get that I'm a little bit crackly But thank you for bearing with me, so get this I recorded all that stuff and then here just a couple of minutes ago I called my dad, who I love, and he's smart and he taught me how to think And I was like, hey dad, I made these episodes about casting lots this week On the podcast, isn't that interesting? And dad was like, well that reminds me of a story one time from a church That I passed her when you were young And then he started to tell me that story and then I was like, Dad, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop Just save all of that so I can hear it for the first time I'm gonna put you on a microphone and we're gonna do this and share it with everybody So guess what, my dad has been here this whole time with you and me right here on the phone Hi dad My great-grandfather in the background You were sneaky, you did a good job, you didn't make any weird grunts or clicks Or anything, like you were just quiet, it was very good Okay, alright Okay, for the uninitiated, my dad's name is Rex Whitman He's a longtime Baptist pastor And he's a very good husband and a very good dad and a very good thinker And he sits around and reads and studies all the time and is just wonderful For bouncing ideas off of on things like this And so he started to tell me the story and now you know who you're listening to So dad, now I would like to hear your story about that thing that casting lots reminded you of Okay, well in years of ministry, one of the things that never happened or rarely, if ever, was casting lots Except for one church We were up in northern Colorado, it was a church that we were planting And we were donated a building to plant the church in But the congregation was small and we were faced with a decision on whether to keep these wooden floors that we had in the sanctuary Or if we were going to do a carpet in the sanctuary And we were puzzling over what to do, we took a vote and the vote came out 50-50 It was exactly even Even between, wait, what were the two ideas again? To leave the floor as a wooden floor or to carpet it in the sanctuary Gotcha And it would have been divisive It would have divided the congregation had we gone one way or the other And one of the men in the congregation said, well, why don't we draw lots? They do that in the Bible And we said, well, that's a great idea, so on a Sunday morning Before we were very far into the worship service We, Charlie was his name, came forward and he had, I think it was two pencils of different lengths And we decided which one represented the wooden floor and which one represented the carpet And we simply drew lots and it came out the wooden floor And so the church did not buy carpet and the unity of the church was maintained And it was a beautiful church anyway, I don't think anybody was cranky But we did want to protect the unity And so everybody agreed beforehand almost like a lawsuit or something Where you avoid going to court in favor of third party mediation Everybody just agreed that the third party mediator would be the drawing of lots And hopefully God is behind the decision That's right, and so we prayed and we drew the lots And it came up the wooden floor And the unity of the church was maintained And everybody agreed to it In advance and afterwards And there was never a peep about what we do About the floor in the sanctuary So the drawing of lots served a valuable purpose From a practical standpoint, as a church planter, trying to maintain unity In a very young and tender church That if they had gone through a split would have been devastating to that congregation And so the drawing of lots really was a part of the history of the establishing of that church That's interesting because it seems like the public nature of it was really important We've been looking at Esther 3 And I'd never noticed before that it wasn't just Haman Who cast the poor, who cast the lot It says they And the antecedent there I wasn't able to detect for sure They might refer to the royal officials Who questioned Mordecai about not bowing to Haman And then reported that to Haman Or it might refer to diviners or court magicians I don't know, it said they cast a lot So there was a group of people there to do it And it seems like That at least semi-public nature of what they did there was meant to give it legitimacy And he got the worst outcome possible Because he cast the lot on the first month And it came up the 12th month So he had to wait 11 months to do his thing And he clearly wanted to do it But apparently it was binding In part because there were other witnesses to this I think if you guys got together as an elder board And you cast lots in private And then you came out and were like Well we cast lots and All of the carpet people lost Sorry, but there were lots I don't think it would have worked I think the fact that everybody just agreed to abide by it And then that it happened in front of their faces I think it seems to me at least that that played a factor Does that make sense or do you think it would have worked just as well if you'd done it in private? No, it needed to be public And part of our model that we were thinking of Was the passage in Acts Where Judas was replaced by Matthias Yeah, that's one of the examples that came up this week Yeah And so we were saying this needs to be public It needs to be everyone involved in it Because we assumed that it was the 11 that drew lots Or at least were present at that drawing of the lots And so it needed to be public And so that's why we did it on a Sunday morning And it was a part of our worship service On that particular Sunday Was the drawing of lots That was the one and only kind We ever used the drawing of lots In 45 years of ministry But it was very valuable Yeah, I don't remember that being a common practice I mean generally speaking If I were to make a spectrum of Christians Who I know And at one end I would put the mystical Christians Who have lots of spiritual practices And do lots of things That they believe give them unique personal guidance from God And at the other end of the spectrum I put the Christians who are very non-mystical They tend to be very logical Very rational Bible oriented Kind of solve it that way I would put you very far to the non-mystical end Of the spectrum of Christians I know But the lot thing It kind of sounds a little bit mystical How is that different From some of the other mystical practices That people might employ to try to seek the will of God? Well I think for us we had A very clear decision You know one way or the other I think even with picking an apostle They had directives and requirements That came before they ever drew the lots So there was a limitation To all of the factors that went into this decision They had to be present and have seen the entire Ministry of Christ and been witness to the resurrection And so there were limiting factors to the lots That directed that decision And so I think there's probably some type of limiting factors I don't think you can just draw a lot And say, where should I live in the world? You might as well throw a dart at a map And decide that But if you say, well I want a city where there are good schools Where there's good entertainment Where there's good shopping Where I know people or people are friendly You limit that and then you make a decision Well I think even with the lots There was a limiting of the decisions before the lot was cast So you wouldn't have cast lots in church If the two agenda items were Alright, if it's the long pencil We're going to carpet the floor If it's the short pencil We're going to become a Satanist church You wouldn't leave that decision to lots What I'm hearing you say is that You were properly stuck You were at a decisional impasse And you felt like either option could perfectly fit within the will of God I don't know, maybe you wanted carpet, maybe you didn't I don't know, I mean I'm kind of making light of it But at the same time, that expense has a big deal For a fledgling church that's still in its vulnerable phase And so it was a real issue And it needed to be taken seriously And maybe God did have a thing that he wanted But you could at least see how both of these would move things forward in a good way And so this really was as much as anything an unsticking mechanism Is that fair? Yeah, we weren't, you know, either of those decisions You could say are in the will of God There was no moral issue involved in either of them It was limited in the choices that were made And it was a simple way to handle all of that And I think it served us well Okay, let me ask you this What would be the ethical difference between what you did there And the following situation All the circumstances are the same Carpet, no carpet Fledging church, we don't have a lot of money What are we going to do here? Well, Charlie has proposed that we are going to gut a chicken And he's pretty good at looking at its entrails And we're going to sift through that on Sunday morning And whatever the bowels of the chicken tell us That's what we will do What would be the difference between casting lots and that? Well, one is very definite The other calls for a lot of interpretation And I think lots By their very nature had a very limited interpretation That you couldn't, you know, you couldn't look at a chicken gizzard And make a major life decision Although people did that, you know, in pagan situations But it seems like the most we see in Judaism Or in the early church Was in this practice of lots And it's very defined, it's very limited And so I think it was, there was a protection And I think it also protected the unity of the early church And so it may have been used more commonly In the early church than now Hmm I have been in places in life Where I have had two right choices in front of me And it was very hard to get unstuck Because I need to do something The only bad choice would be nothing But which of the two good right choices I take Is very challenging And a few times without casting lots, I guess, in my life I've just been like, well, I've got to pick one And today, I feel like that one Tomorrow, I'll probably feel like the other But I'm going with option A Because today's the day I made the choice And that's what I felt like, and I just got to get unstuck And so it's an interesting remedy to decision-making paralysis That, I guess I haven't even really thought much about Until the last few days here Looking at this passage in Esther And it's just a surprise direction I didn't see my thought processes going And looking at this passage is kind of interesting You know, I think at times we tend to think of the will of God as a dot A tiny little dot somewhere out there in space And we launch a prayer or a missile And we hope we hit it But if we miss it, we're going to go forever Into the outer darkness and never return Or you can say that the will of God is not a dot, it's a circle And within that circle, there are choices that are both Or even more than both, maybe three or four or five choices All within the will of God And if you choose a wooden floor Or a carpeted floor God is pleased either way And I think when you see the will of God as a circle rather than a dot It gives you that flexibility to operate without getting all tense And like, what if I miss this And what if I, you know, fly past the target that is the dot labeled God's will And go forever into this black outer darkness of space And my life is ruined because I put on the wrong shirt today Yeah, that's thoughtful And it's interesting because the school I went to in high school There were teachers there who had that kind of single point of light in the darkness And that is the one place that is the will of God You got to divine it and you got to get to it And I struggled to resonate with what they were trying to teach me But in that same institution, there were other teachers who were saying something more like what you're saying And as I've grown up and thought about the Bible more I've, you know, I'm resonating much, much more with your description But let me throw out a question Would you say that God knows in advance and necessarily by merit of his being the supreme being That he already knows what all of those choices are going to be Or can he be surprised by what you pick? I think he knows what choice we will make Because he knows our character He knows the future, he's the omnipotent God But I think the age old question is does that lead to causality? Does that mean that he causes that decision? Do we truly have a free will? And I think God can direct without causing It is not always an inevitable case of causation Now, when you look at Proverbs, and I can't quote the exact verse But there's a verse in Proverbs and I'll try to summarize it It's to the effect of the lot is cast into the lap But God decides the outcome Yeah, you pretty soon nailed it. That's 1633 We talked about it earlier this week Yeah, the lot is cast into the lap, but it's every decision is from the Lord And it's the NIB rendering Yeah, and so the question is, is that decision a dot or a circle? And it may be that God is directing In some of those sort of nebulous situations Where three or four or five things are all in his will And there may have been more Disciples than Matthias Who are appointed who could have filled the place that Judas left vacant What do you mean by could of though? Like could have the light of I mean they were qualified They filled the requirements for the position Then being there still In sort of like advanced to the redemptive plan It wouldn't have derailed or wrecked like the whole point of everything God's doing Yeah, and I think even there I doesn't indicate what two choices to decide from And so even there it was a limited decision to seek the will of God And so either one of those could have been right And does God enter into that casting of a lot He probably does in some way You know, I know that sounds mystical But but but I think You know, he can say, all right, this is Either of these are fine You want my direction cast a lot And it's going to happen But either way is right Whether God directs the role of that dice In this case, we'll call it a dice Or whether it's pure chance It's either God directs it Or that the choices are limited And that either choice is within his will But either way God's will is gone Okay, agree or disagree with the following statement God knew in advance the outcome of every dice role in the history of existence You don't ask easy questions, you know, right? Well, I'm going past the easy questions I mean, were there any of those roles of the dice at any point in human history A literal physical dice getting rolled on a board Where God was like, oh, wow, I thought that was going to be a two Five's okay also, I guess Yeah, no, God is not surprised by that But again, coming back to our decisions God may not be surprised by the role of the dice And he's not surprised by our decisions And in a way, there's a parallel Between the role of the dice and what will we decide But God then can be sovereign And allow us the freedom to choose He can allow the dice to roll to whatever it wants to be But he knows it just as he knows our decision without causing that decision to occur I think it's wild that out of the Book of Esther we get a holiday literally named for a dice Just, I mean, on the surface what you're celebrating is the deliverance of the Jews, obviously But at the secondary level, what you're also celebrating and being reminded of is God even when you do not see him is unsurprised and in complete control And sovereign in his reign is power over everything And I think, I think ultimately You and I might frame that a little different in terms of how we would set up the conundrum Of human agency and God's sovereignty But I think we end up in the same place, which is all the emphasis is on the sovereignty of God I don't see a necessary conflict, and I don't think you do either between human decision-making And God's foreknowledge of everything Foreknowledge is not necessarily the same thing as causation And I just think the best we can do on this topic is to think about it in pretty linear ways When in reality only one of the two characters in the equation is linear, that's us I mean, God is infinite, unbound by anything, so it's hard to calculate using the normal methods of calculation That we do, the relationship between us and our journey through time in a linear way And God, and his very much other all-powerful unlimited-ness It's just, it makes sense, I guess, that that would be a tricky question And I think if that tricky question didn't exist within the history of Christian thought I would have some suspicions about the genuineness of Christian thought in general That tension must exist Well, it's like the little boy who plays checkers And he's playing against a grandmaster who's playing four-dimensional chess And he doesn't understand the moves of the four-dimensional chess master And God is playing four dimensions or ten dimensions of chess While we're the little boy playing learning to play checkers for the first time And so we are not going to fully understand all of those mysteries We can take some guesses as to what's going on But I think the debate will probably continue for another few thousand years Before we ever get it, fully figured out And in the meantime, I think we can be gracious to one another along the way Yeah, I like your style on that That's very thoughtful stuff Thank you for jumping in and thinking about it with me I told people here earlier this week, a couple days ago, or something about the book you wrote House Church now Yeah, mm-hmm I kind of gave him the quick rundown Did you listen to that episode? Did you hear what I said? No, I haven't heard it, but I'm assuming you said some nice stuff about me in the book Yeah, it was generally nice Okay, good Okay, real quick, what's the elevator pitch? Why are you excited about the book? What do you think somebody would get out of reading it? Well, I'm excited about the book because it's going back to the first century And saying, before all of the liturgy, before all the robes Before all of the smoke and lights and production What did the simplicity of the early church look like? And just as, and I'll use an illustration here When people came across on the Oregon Trail And I'm a westerner, I grew up just probably two miles north of the Oregon Trail And yet one of the things in the 1800s People would arrive at their destination But yet you'd see that they had cast aside things along the trail You know, they come to a hill and it's like We can't get up this hill, let's throw out our pump organ And we leave it by the side of the trail And there were things like that along the Oregon Trail Well, I look at the early church and I wonder if the simplicity of the early church Wasn't something that maybe we threw away And later when we've arrived at our present destination in our modern world If we look back and say, you know, we left something pretty precious back there I wonder if we should go back and get it And I guess that's kind of a question And sort of the basic principle of the book Is maybe we left something along the trail Maybe we left something in the past that was valuable And we need to go back and look at it and maybe reclaim it So there's the theme of the book in a nutshell Okay, and everybody we're going to put the link down below in the show notes So if you want to go check that out, it's on Amazon or you can go down there Thanks in advance for even considering checking it out I'm grateful to my dad, I'm proud of my dad and I wanted you to know about his book So appreciate you hanging in here for a longer than usual Saturday bonus episode conversation And thanks for the hospitality that you all just showed my dad I appreciate that too Thanks dad And thank you for inviting me Yeah, you bet, I love you, talk to you soon I love you too, bye-bye Thank you for watching

segments.text: Bonus episode, a bonus episode
Of the 10 minute Bible hour podcast
It's a bonus episode, a bonus episode
Of the 10 minute Bible hour podcast
Come on now!
Hey everybody, it's Matt, this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast
And if you happen to be listening to this in real time, then you're like, wait a minute, this is Saturday
We don't do this on Saturdays, but you're wrong!
Sometimes we do it on Saturdays, this is one of those days
I thought we just had a really fun week of talking about the biblical concept of casting lots and dice and
Cleromancy and using some form of what looks on the surface like chance to determine the will of God
It's an odd practice, I'm not saying do that or don't do that
But what I am saying is that all those examples that we came up with
Mostly at the top of my head, really easily and really quickly throughout the Bible
There's none of them cast a negative light on the practice or discourage it
At worst, the treatment by the biblical authors is indifference or neutrality
And at best, the indication is, no, I mean casting lots in that situation
Was a way to figure out the will of God or at least to get unstuck and move forward
And I'm very sorry for my voice, this has been a long journey for me, so I get that I'm a little bit crackly
But thank you for bearing with me, so get this
I recorded all that stuff and then here just a couple of minutes ago
I called my dad, who I love, and he's smart and he taught me how to think
And I was like, hey dad, I made these episodes about casting lots this week
On the podcast, isn't that interesting?
And dad was like, well that reminds me of a story one time from a church
That I passed her when you were young
And then he started to tell me that story and then I was like, Dad, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop
Just save all of that so I can hear it for the first time
I'm gonna put you on a microphone and we're gonna do this and share it with everybody
So guess what, my dad has been here this whole time with you and me right here on the phone
Hi dad
My great-grandfather in the background
You were sneaky, you did a good job, you didn't make any weird grunts or clicks
Or anything, like you were just quiet, it was very good
Okay, alright
Okay, for the uninitiated, my dad's name is Rex Whitman
He's a longtime Baptist pastor
And he's a very good husband and a very good dad and a very good thinker
And he sits around and reads and studies all the time and is just wonderful
For bouncing ideas off of on things like this
And so he started to tell me the story and now you know who you're listening to
So dad, now I would like to hear your story about that thing that casting lots reminded you of
Okay, well in years of ministry, one of the things that never happened or rarely, if ever, was casting lots
Except for one church
We were up in northern Colorado, it was a church that we were planting
And we were donated a building to plant the church in
But the congregation was small and we were faced with a decision on whether to keep these wooden floors that we had in the sanctuary
Or if we were going to do a carpet in the sanctuary
And we were puzzling over what to do, we took a vote and the vote came out 50-50
It was exactly even
Even between, wait, what were the two ideas again?
To leave the floor as a wooden floor or to carpet it in the sanctuary
Gotcha
And it would have been divisive
It would have divided the congregation had we gone one way or the other
And one of the men in the congregation said, well, why don't we draw lots?
They do that in the Bible
And we said, well, that's a great idea, so on a Sunday morning
Before we were very far into the worship service
We, Charlie was his name, came forward and he had, I think it was two pencils of different lengths
And we decided which one represented the wooden floor and which one represented the carpet
And we simply drew lots and it came out the wooden floor
And so the church did not buy carpet and the unity of the church was maintained
And it was a beautiful church anyway, I don't think anybody was cranky
But we did want to protect the unity
And so everybody agreed beforehand almost like a lawsuit or something
Where you avoid going to court in favor of third party mediation
Everybody just agreed that the third party mediator would be the drawing of lots
And hopefully God is behind the decision
That's right, and so we prayed and we drew the lots
And it came up the wooden floor
And the unity of the church was maintained
And everybody agreed to it
In advance and afterwards
And there was never a peep about what we do
About the floor in the sanctuary
So the drawing of lots served a valuable purpose
From a practical standpoint, as a church planter, trying to maintain unity
In a very young and tender church
That if they had gone through a split would have been devastating to that congregation
And so the drawing of lots really was a part of the history of the establishing of that church
That's interesting because it seems like the public nature of it was really important
We've been looking at Esther 3
And I'd never noticed before that it wasn't just Haman
Who cast the poor, who cast the lot
It says they
And the antecedent there I wasn't able to detect for sure
They might refer to the royal officials
Who questioned Mordecai about not bowing to Haman
And then reported that to Haman
Or it might refer to diviners or court magicians
I don't know, it said they cast a lot
So there was a group of people there to do it
And it seems like
That at least semi-public nature of what they did there was meant to give it legitimacy
And he got the worst outcome possible
Because he cast the lot on the first month
And it came up the 12th month
So he had to wait 11 months to do his thing
And he clearly wanted to do it
But apparently it was binding
In part because there were other witnesses to this
I think if you guys got together as an elder board
And you cast lots in private
And then you came out and were like
Well we cast lots and
All of the carpet people lost
Sorry, but there were lots
I don't think it would have worked
I think the fact that everybody just agreed to abide by it
And then that it happened in front of their faces
I think it seems to me at least that that played a factor
Does that make sense or do you think it would have worked just as well if you'd done it in private?
No, it needed to be public
And part of our model that we were thinking of
Was the passage in Acts
Where Judas was replaced by Matthias
Yeah, that's one of the examples that came up this week
Yeah
And so we were saying this needs to be public
It needs to be everyone involved in it
Because we assumed that it was the 11 that drew lots
Or at least were present at that drawing of the lots
And so it needed to be public
And so that's why we did it on a Sunday morning
And it was a part of our worship service
On that particular Sunday
Was the drawing of lots
That was the one and only kind
We ever used the drawing of lots
In 45 years of ministry
But it was very valuable
Yeah, I don't remember that being a common practice
I mean generally speaking
If I were to make a spectrum of Christians
Who I know
And at one end I would put the mystical Christians
Who have lots of spiritual practices
And do lots of things
That they believe give them unique personal guidance from God
And at the other end of the spectrum
I put the Christians who are very non-mystical
They tend to be very logical
Very rational Bible oriented
Kind of solve it that way
I would put you very far to the non-mystical end
Of the spectrum of Christians I know
But the lot thing
It kind of sounds a little bit mystical
How is that different
From some of the other mystical practices
That people might employ to try to seek the will of God?
Well I think for us we had
A very clear decision
You know one way or the other
I think even with picking an apostle
They had directives and requirements
That came before they ever drew the lots
So there was a limitation
To all of the factors that went into this decision
They had to be present and have seen the entire
Ministry of Christ and been witness to the resurrection
And so there were limiting factors to the lots
That directed that decision
And so I think there's probably some type of limiting factors
I don't think you can just draw a lot
And say, where should I live in the world?
You might as well throw a dart at a map
And decide that
But if you say, well I want a city where there are good schools
Where there's good entertainment
Where there's good shopping
Where I know people or people are friendly
You limit that and then you make a decision
Well I think even with the lots
There was a limiting of the decisions before the lot was cast
So you wouldn't have cast lots in church
If the two agenda items were
Alright, if it's the long pencil
We're going to carpet the floor
If it's the short pencil
We're going to become a Satanist church
You wouldn't leave that decision to lots
What I'm hearing you say is that
You were properly stuck
You were at a decisional impasse
And you felt like either option could
perfectly fit within the will of God
I don't know, maybe you wanted carpet, maybe you didn't
I don't know, I mean I'm kind of making light of it
But at the same time, that expense has a big deal
For a fledgling church that's still in its vulnerable phase
And so it was a real issue
And it needed to be taken seriously
And maybe God did have a thing that he wanted
But you could at least see how both of these would move things forward in a good way
And so this really was as much as anything an unsticking mechanism
Is that fair?
Yeah, we weren't, you know, either of those decisions
You could say are in the will of God
There was no moral issue involved in either of them
It was limited in the choices that were made
And it was a simple way to handle all of that
And I think it served us well
Okay, let me ask you this
What would be the ethical difference between what you did there
And the following situation
All the circumstances are the same
Carpet, no carpet
Fledging church, we don't have a lot of money
What are we going to do here?
Well, Charlie has proposed that we are going to gut a chicken
And he's pretty good at looking at its entrails
And we're going to sift through that on Sunday morning
And whatever the bowels of the chicken tell us
That's what we will do
What would be the difference between casting lots and that?
Well, one is very definite
The other calls for a lot of interpretation
And I think lots
By their very nature had a very limited interpretation
That you couldn't, you know, you couldn't look at a chicken gizzard
And make a major life decision
Although people did that, you know, in pagan situations
But it seems like the most we see in Judaism
Or in the early church
Was in this practice of lots
And it's very defined, it's very limited
And so I think it was, there was a protection
And I think it also protected the unity of the early church
And so it may have been used more commonly
In the early church than now
Hmm
I have been in places in life
Where I have had two right choices in front of me
And it was very hard to get unstuck
Because I need to do something
The only bad choice would be nothing
But which of the two good right choices I take
Is very challenging
And a few times without casting lots, I guess, in my life
I've just been like, well, I've got to pick one
And today, I feel like that one
Tomorrow, I'll probably feel like the other
But I'm going with option A
Because today's the day I made the choice
And that's what I felt like, and I just got to get unstuck
And so it's an interesting remedy to decision-making paralysis
That, I guess I haven't even really thought much about
Until the last few days here
Looking at this passage in Esther
And it's just a surprise direction
I didn't see my thought processes going
And looking at this passage is kind of interesting
You know, I think at times we tend to think of the will of God as a dot
A tiny little dot somewhere out there in space
And we launch a prayer or a missile
And we hope we hit it
But if we miss it, we're going to go forever
Into the outer darkness and never return
Or you can say that the will of God is not a dot, it's a circle
And within that circle, there are choices that are both
Or even more than both, maybe three or four or five choices
All within the will of God
And if you choose a wooden floor
Or a carpeted floor
God is pleased either way
And I think when you see the will of God as a circle rather than a dot
It gives you that flexibility to operate without getting all tense
And like, what if I miss this
And what if I, you know, fly past the target that is the dot labeled God's will
And go forever into this black outer darkness of space
And my life is ruined because I put on the wrong shirt today
Yeah, that's thoughtful
And it's interesting because the school I went to in high school
There were teachers there who had that kind of single point of light in the darkness
And that is the one place that is the will of God
You got to divine it and you got to get to it
And I struggled to resonate with what they were trying to teach me
But in that same institution, there were other teachers who were saying something more like what you're saying
And as I've grown up and thought about the Bible more
I've, you know, I'm resonating much, much more with your description
But let me throw out a question
Would you say that God knows in advance and necessarily by merit of his being the supreme being
That he already knows what all of those choices are going to be
Or can he be surprised by what you pick?
I think he knows what choice we will make
Because he knows our character
He knows the future, he's the omnipotent God
But I think the age old question is does that lead to causality?
Does that mean that he causes that decision?
Do we truly have a free will?
And I think God can direct without causing
It is not always an inevitable case of causation
Now, when you look at Proverbs, and I can't quote the exact verse
But there's a verse in Proverbs and I'll try to summarize it
It's to the effect of the lot is cast into the lap
But God decides the outcome
Yeah, you pretty soon nailed it. That's 1633
We talked about it earlier this week
Yeah, the lot is cast into the lap, but it's every decision is from the Lord
And it's the NIB rendering
Yeah, and so the question is, is that decision a dot or a circle?
And it may be that God is directing
In some of those sort of nebulous situations
Where three or four or five things are all in his will
And there may have been more
Disciples than Matthias
Who are appointed who could have filled the place that Judas left vacant
What do you mean by could of though?
Like could have the light of
I mean they were qualified
They filled the requirements for the position
Then being there still
In sort of like advanced to the redemptive plan
It wouldn't have derailed or wrecked like the whole point of everything God's doing
Yeah, and I think even there
I doesn't indicate what two choices to decide from
And so even there it was a limited decision to seek the will of God
And so either one of those could have been right
And does God enter into that casting of a lot
He probably does in some way
You know, I know that sounds mystical
But but but I think
You know, he can say, all right, this is
Either of these are fine
You want my direction cast a lot
And it's going to happen
But either way is right
Whether God directs the role of that dice
In this case, we'll call it a dice
Or whether it's pure chance
It's either God directs it
Or that the choices are limited
And that either choice is within his will
But either way God's will is gone
Okay, agree or disagree with the following statement
God knew in advance the outcome of every dice role in the history of existence
You don't ask easy questions, you know, right?
Well, I'm going past the easy questions
I mean, were there any of those roles of the dice at any point in human history
A literal physical dice getting rolled on a board
Where God was like, oh, wow, I thought that was going to be a two
Five's okay also, I guess
Yeah, no, God is not surprised by that
But again, coming back to our decisions
God may not be surprised by the role of the dice
And he's not surprised by our decisions
And in a way, there's a parallel
Between the role of the dice and what will we decide
But God then can be sovereign
And allow us the freedom to choose
He can allow the dice to roll to whatever it wants to be
But he knows it just as he knows our decision without causing that decision to occur
I think it's wild that out of the Book of Esther we get a holiday literally named for a dice
Just, I mean, on the surface what you're celebrating is the deliverance of the Jews, obviously
But at the secondary level, what you're also celebrating and being reminded of is
God even when you do not see him is unsurprised and in complete control
And sovereign in his reign is power over everything
And I think, I think ultimately
You and I might frame that a little different in terms of how we would set up the conundrum
Of human agency and God's sovereignty
But I think we end up in the same place, which is all the emphasis is on the sovereignty of God
I don't see a necessary conflict, and I don't think you do either between human decision-making
And God's foreknowledge of everything
Foreknowledge is not necessarily the same thing as causation
And I just think the best we can do on this topic is to think about it in pretty linear ways
When in reality only one of the two characters in the equation is linear, that's us
I mean, God is infinite, unbound by anything, so it's hard to calculate using the normal methods of calculation
That we do, the relationship between us and our journey through time in a linear way
And God, and his very much other all-powerful unlimited-ness
It's just, it makes sense, I guess, that that would be a tricky question
And I think if that tricky question didn't exist within the history of Christian thought
I would have some suspicions about the genuineness of Christian thought in general
That tension must exist
Well, it's like the little boy who plays checkers
And he's playing against a grandmaster who's playing four-dimensional chess
And he doesn't understand the moves of the four-dimensional chess master
And God is playing four dimensions or ten dimensions of chess
While we're the little boy playing learning to play checkers for the first time
And so we are not going to fully understand all of those mysteries
We can take some guesses as to what's going on
But I think the debate will probably continue for another few thousand years
Before we ever get it, fully figured out
And in the meantime, I think we can be gracious to one another along the way
Yeah, I like your style on that
That's very thoughtful stuff
Thank you for jumping in and thinking about it with me
I told people here earlier this week, a couple days ago, or something about the book you wrote
House Church now
Yeah, mm-hmm
I kind of gave him the quick rundown
Did you listen to that episode? Did you hear what I said?
No, I haven't heard it, but I'm assuming you said some nice stuff about me in the book
Yeah, it was generally nice
Okay, good
Okay, real quick, what's the elevator pitch? Why are you excited about the book?
What do you think somebody would get out of reading it?
Well, I'm excited about the book because it's going back to the first century
And saying, before all of the liturgy, before all the robes
Before all of the smoke and lights and production
What did the simplicity of the early church look like?
And just as, and I'll use an illustration here
When people came across on the Oregon Trail
And I'm a westerner, I grew up just probably two miles north of the Oregon Trail
And yet one of the things in the 1800s
People would arrive at their destination
But yet you'd see that they had cast aside things along the trail
You know, they come to a hill and it's like
We can't get up this hill, let's throw out our pump organ
And we leave it by the side of the trail
And there were things like that along the Oregon Trail
Well, I look at the early church and I wonder if the simplicity of the early church
Wasn't something that maybe we threw away
And later when we've arrived at our present destination in our modern world
If we look back and say, you know, we left something pretty precious back there
I wonder if we should go back and get it
And I guess that's kind of a question
And sort of the basic principle of the book
Is maybe we left something along the trail
Maybe we left something in the past that was valuable
And we need to go back and look at it and maybe reclaim it
So there's the theme of the book in a nutshell
Okay, and everybody we're going to put the link down below in the show notes
So if you want to go check that out, it's on Amazon or you can go down there
Thanks in advance for even considering checking it out
I'm grateful to my dad, I'm proud of my dad and I wanted you to know about his book
So appreciate you hanging in here for a longer than usual Saturday bonus episode conversation
And thanks for the hospitality that you all just showed my dad
I appreciate that too
Thanks dad
And thank you for inviting me
Yeah, you bet, I love you, talk to you soon
I love you too, bye-bye
Thank you for watching
